description: Borrowed from Latin viridis, from vireō (“I am green”). Doublet of vert.

adjectives.description: virid (comparative more virid, superlative most virid)

examples: The palace here, and there a virid mound, / Confine a flow'ry spot of grassy ground.
In January 1208 the king ordered for a chaplain a robe of virid or burnet with a hood of coney skin ‘like our other chaplains’,  […]

description: From virus +‎ -id or from translingual viridae (“a grouping of viruses”), from virus +‎ -idae, from Latin virus (“poison”).

entries.meaning: (usually in the plural) Any of a group of related viruses.
